title: Shock decline keeps UK manufacturing in the doldrums
text:

Wed, Sep 9, 2015, 11:04 BST - UK Markets close in 5 hrs 26 mins Shock decline keeps UK manufacturing in the doldrums By Szu Ping Chan | Telegraph – 2 minutes 31 seconds ago UBGXF 0.00 
Pound falls against the dollar and euro as official data show output at UK factories fell at sharpest pace in more than a year in July 
UK manufacturing suffered a shock decline in July, as the strong pound and global uncertainty continued to hamper activity at Britain's factories. 
Manufacturing output fell by 0.8pc in July compared with June, according to the Office for National Statistics (ONS). 
This was well below economists' estimates for a slight rise of 0.2pc, and represents the steepest decline since May 2014. 
The decline dragged down overall industrial production, which fell by 0.4pc compared with the previous month. 
* Jeremy Warner: Unbalanced but lucky, Britain hits an economic sweet spot * UK manufacturing lurches towards stagnation The ONS said manufacturing, which accounts for around 10pc of UK output, was the only main sector to report a decline in July, sending the pound down by three quarters of a cent against the dollar and half a cent against the euro. 
The ONS said activity at Britain's factories was dragged down by transport equipment and base metal products. 
On an annual basis, total production output rose by 0.8pc in July, boosted by a 6.7pc rise in mining and quarrying output. The sector was given a shot in the arm at the March Budget when the Chancellor announced much-needed tax breaks for the oil and gas sector . Manufacturing output fell by 0.5pc in the year to July. 
The data were released just a day after a report by Oil and Gas UK warned that private investment in the North Sea was forecast to slump by up to £4bn per year through to the end of 2018 as operators slash costs to adapt to lower prices (Other OTC: UBGXF - news ) .
